div.head: The Naval Expedition
div.excerpt: "Of all the rebellious States, South Carolina deserves the severest treatment, and no punishment that can be meted out to her by the General Government, would be considered too severe by the loyal people of the country, though that punishment should sweep over her entire length and breadth as with a besom [sic] of destruction, leaving neither root nor branch, house nor hamlet, master or slave, man or woman."
div.summary: Expresses the opinion that South Carolina deserves to be severely punished for its history of rebellion and its current disloyalty.

div.head: Regulars and Volunteers

transcript.p: The Washington correspondent of the New York Herald says:

The members of Congress who are here are also discussing the propriety of wiping out the distinction between the regulars and volunteers, by declaring the volunteers to compose the army of the United States. Unless something is done to legally obliterate the distinction now maintained, and to do away with the tyrannical rule of the regular department, the volunteer system will be utterly destroyed.--As it is now, no officer, however capable or meritorious, can obtain any position or consideration with the heads of the army bureaus, and nothing is conceded to the volunteers that can possibly be withheld. For their arms, clothing, equipments, transportation, &c., the volunteers must dance attendance, day after day, upon men who openly deride and malign them, and who never treat them with decency, and never speak of them except with contempt. It is astonishing the extent to which this feeling is carried.

div.summary: Points to the ill treatment of the volunteer segment of the army by members of the regular army.

div.head: The Naval Expedition
div.excerpt: "Gen. Sherman has hundreds, perhaps thousand, of negro laborers at his command to work on the new entrenchments. It is said they were wild with joy and revenge. They have been shot down, they say, like dogs, because they would not go off with their masters."

div.head: Fun!

transcript.p: Just as we go to press, we observe that Sanford, the inimitable negro delineator, has posted his bills, announcing a Concert to come off on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings of next week. Upon the recent successes which have attended our arms in the West and South Carolina, we doubt not but that we could be induced to take a hearty laugh--even at Sanford's expense.

div.summary: Reports that Sanford, "the inimitable negro delineator" will give a concern on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings next week.

div.head: Kemmerer's
div.summary: Relates that the Grand Juvenile Concerts and Floral Exhibitions that were presented on Monday and Thursday evenings at Franklin Hall "gave universal satisfaction and delight to crowded houses." Notes that a final performance will be given on Saturday evening.

div.head: A Scoundrel

transcript.p: A man by the name of James Klink, a merchant of Newville, Cumberland County, arrived in this place on Saturday last, accompanied by a young lady whom he represented as his wife, and put up at one of our Hotels for several days.--Klink has a wife and several children in Newville; was an elder in the Church, and occupied a respectable position in that community. The girl, whose ruin he has accomplished, was from a rural district, and became acquainted with Klink by dealing at his store. The elopement was not immediately discovered; but when the face became developed, they were tracked to this place, and on Tuesday last the brother-in-law of the girl, accompanied by Klink's wife, arrived here in pursuit of the guilty pair. By that time, however, the respected merchant had left for parts unknown, having sent the foolish and disgraced girl back--from whence he decoyed her.

div.summary: Reports that James Klink, a merchant from Connecticut, brought a girl into town the previous Saturday. Klink has a wife and children and by staying with her at a hotel in Chambersburg for several days has accomplished the "ruin" of the girl involved.
